data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

data.weatherInfo: Due to the length of the California National Historic Trail, be sure to consult local weather sources for the region you'll be visiting. Check out the forecast with the National Weather Service and search for the area you'd like to visit: weather.gov
data.name: California

multimedia.title: Alcove Spring – Place to visit on the Oregon & California national historic trails
Ash Hollow/Windlass Hill – Places to visit on the Oregon & California national historic trails

data.description: Described by California Trail emigrants as “a city of tall spires,” “steeple rocks,” and “the silent city,” this awe-inspiring landscape continues to captivate. Today, it beckons rock climbers, hikers, campers, hunters, and adventurers with its dramatic scenery, fascinating geology, and echoes of the Old West. The Silent City is ready for you to explore.
data.directionsInfo: From Boise: take I-84 East to exit 216 (Declo); go south on Highway 77 to Conner Creek Junction; turn right (west) on Highway 77 Spur to Almo. The visitor center and the park entrance are south of the post office and businesses. From Pocatello: take I-86 West to I-84 West to exit 216 and proceed as above. From Salt Lake City: take I-84 west to exit 245 (Sublette), turn left and go west to Malta. From Malta take Highway 77. Take Highway 77 Spur to Almo.

operatingHours.description:
The National Reserve is open 365 days a year, 7 days a week, 24 hours a day.  Many roads are not maintained during the winter and may become impassable from late November through March. For current conditions visitors are encouraged to check with the Visitor Center or watch for alerts on our website and social media.

During summer the Visitor Center is open every day 8:00 am to 4:30 pm. During fall/winter the Visitor Center is open 8:00 am to 4:30 pm Tuesday-Saturday, closed Sundays, Mondays, and holidays.
operatingHours.name: City of Rocks National Reserve

images.title: City of Rocks Granite
images.altText: Snow dusted granite formations jut up from a mountainous juniper covered landscape.
images.caption: Explore the City

images.title: City of Rocks
images.altText: 3 silhouetted foggy granite formations highlighted by golden sunlight.
images.caption: City of Rocks offers sweeping vistas and awe-inspiring scenery.

images.title: Indian Grove Overlook
images.altText: Grand scenic view looking down from a high elevation. Granite spires jut up from the landscape.
images.caption: The majority of outcrops in City of Rocks and all of the pinnacles are either Almo Pluton or Green Creek Complex granite.

images.title: Twin Sisters
images.altText: Two granite pinnacles right next to each other that are similar in size and shape.
images.caption: Twin Sisters may be similar in size and shape, but one is 2.5 billion years old, the younger sister is only 28 million years old.

images.title: Window Arch at City of Rocks
images.altText: A granite arch is displayed on the horizon
images.caption: Forces of nature sculpt unexpected features in granite such as Window Arch

images.title: Replica Emigrant Wagons at City of Rocks
images.altText: Replica emigrant wagons rest unhitched at sunrise
images.caption: Nearly 250,000 California-bound emigrants traveled through City of Rocks (1843-1882)

images.title: Emigrant Signatures at City of Rocks
images.altText: Emigrant signature written with axle-grease on granite
images.caption: California-bound emigrants painted their signature on Register Rock in 1850

images.title: Climber on Morning Glory Spire
images.altText: A climber ascends a granite spire with mountains in the distance.
images.caption: Over half of the 100,000 annual visitors to City of Rocks come to experience climbing

images.title: Window Arch
images.altText: Granite arch with sunset peeking through.
images.caption: Window Arch is one of many impressive rock features found in City of Rocks.

images.title: Silent City of Rocks
images.altText: Snowy granite pinnacles.
images.caption: Winter is a great time to experience quiet and solitude in City of Rocks.

data.weatherInfo: City of Rocks is located in south-central Idaho within the northern edge of the Basin and Range geologic province. Outdoor recreation can be pleasant from April through October. Summers are generally dry with 10 to 15 inches of precipitation in winter and spring. Summer temperatures range widely with night time lows occasionally approaching freezing and midday highs nearing 100° F; however, the typical range of low and high temperature is 45-85. Thunderstorms are common in the summer months (June - August)
data.name: City Of Rocks

data.fullName: Craters Of The Moon National Monument & Preserve
data.description: Craters of the Moon is a vast ocean of lava flows with scattered islands of cinder cones and sagebrush. We invite you to explore this "weird and scenic landscape" where yesterday's volcanic events are likely to continue tomorrow.

entranceFees.description: This per-vehicle fee applies to private, non-commercial vehicles and provides entrance into the park for seven consecutive days. The fee covers the driver and any passengers.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This motorcycle fee provides entrance into the park for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: This per-vehicle fee applies to commercial vehicles and provides entrance into the park for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: This per-person fee provides entrance into the park for seven consecutive days. Youth age 15 and under are free.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Classes or groups from accredited academic institutions may apply for a fee waiver ahead of their visit by contacting the park. Academic fee waivers are not granted automatically. Educational groups must apply and meet the two criteria to receive a fee waiver: 1) eligibility and 2) educational purpose and relevance of park resources or facilities. Groups that choose to not make a reservation or apply for an academic fee waiver will be charged the standard entrance fee per vehicle.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Education/Academic Groups

entranceFees.description: This per-vehicle fee applies to commercial vehicles and provides entrance into the park for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entranceFees.description: This per-vehicle fee applies to commercial vehicles and provides entrance into the park for seven consecutive days.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entrancePasses.description: Annual entrance pass for Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve only. Valid for one year through the month of purchase. This pass can be purchased at the park entrance station.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Visitor Center and Loop Drive are located 18 miles southwest of Arco, Idaho on U.S. Highway 20/26/93, 24 miles northeast of Carey, Idaho on U.S. Highway 20/26/93, 84 miles from Idaho Falls, and 90 miles from Twin Falls. Physical address is 1266 Craters Loop Road(Lat/Long: 43° 27.711'N/113° 33.7) Access to the main visitor use area is via a paved highway. Unpaved roads provide additional access to the BLM monument and NPS Preserve but should only be utilized by four wheel drive and high clearance vehicles.

operatingHours.description: The Loop Road is typically open from mid April through late November. High clearance four-wheel drive is highly recommended on BLM Monument roads and are impassible when snow or water is present.
operatingHours.name: Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve

operatingHours.description: The scenic Loop Road is open to vehicles as conditions allow. The Loop Road is generally open to motorized vehicles from late April through late November.
operatingHours.name: Craters of the Moon National Monument

addresses.line1: Craters of the Moon National Monument
Craters of the Moon National Monument and Preserve

images.title: A Sea of Lava
images.altText: A close-up shot of a folded, waving sea of lava rock, with mountains in the far distance.
images.caption: Craters of the Moon features the largest young lava field in the lower 48 states, encompassing the entire Great Rift volcanic zone.

images.title: Wildflowers on the Moon
images.altText: Small purple flowers and larger white flowers with reddish stems grow out of black volcanic rock
images.caption: Spectacular floral displays occur at Craters each spring, including this dwarf monkeyflower and bitterroot.

images.title: Stargazing at Craters
images.altText: The Craters entrance sign sits below a starry night sky, with the milky way brightly-lit.
images.caption: Craters of the Moon was designated an International Dark Sky Park in 2017, making it one of the best places in the country to stargaze.

images.title: Exploring the Craters
images.altText: A figure stands inside a large lava tube on a pile of rubble, lit by a round opening overhead.
images.caption: Many visitors come to Craters to explore its unique and fragile lava tubes.

images.title: Explore Craters on Foot
images.altText: A paved trail winds up around the side of a spatter cone.
images.caption: Trails at Craters, like the Spatter Cone Trail, allow visitors to explore young volcanic features like spatter cones, cinder cones, and lava fields.

images.title: A Weird and Scenic Landscape
images.altText: A panoramic view across the Craters landscape, bisected by a winding road.
images.caption: Craters of the Moon features unexpectedly stunning views, such as this panoramic vista from the top of Inferno Cone.

data.weatherInfo: Weather at Craters of the Moon is characterized by hot summers and cold winters. In February, average snow depth ranges from 26 inches at the north end of the monument to just 2 inches at the south end. Intense summer sun bakes the black lava, generating surface temperatures of 170°F and air temperatures in the 90s. Drying winds are a daily occurrence, especially in the afternoon, and may reach 15 to 30 miles per hour.
data.name: Craters Of The Moon

data.description: During the Pliocene, this place looked quite different. Lush wetlands, forests, and grasslands provided excellent habitat for a variety of animals. From fascinating, now-extinct creatures like the saber-toothed cat, mastodon, and ground sloth, to more familiar animals like horses, beavers, and birds, the scientific study of Pliocene fossils is the key to Hagerman.
data.directionsInfo: The Thousand Springs Visitor Center is located about one mile north of downtown Hagerman on US Highway 30.

operatingHours.description:
The road leading to the Monument is a public road and is open 24 hours a day.  
Access to the Monument Overlooks closes at dusk.  The Visitor Center has separate hours.

Please be aware that the overlooks and trails are not maintained during winter.
operatingHours.name: Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument

images.title: Fossil Exhibits at the Thousand Springs Visitor Center
images.altText: A fossil horse stands in the center of a room filled with posters and display cases
images.caption: The Thousand Springs Visitor Center is the only place at the monument to see fossils.

images.title: Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument in Southern Idaho
images.altText: Steep, rocky bluffs line a river, awash in warm sunset colors
images.caption: The Glenns Ferry Formation contains one of the world's richest Pliocene fossil deposits.

images.title: Thousand Springs Visitor Center
images.altText: A sidewalk leads to a boxy, wood-paneled building labelled as "visitor center"
images.caption: The Thousand Springs Visitor Center, opening in 2022, marks a new partnership between the National Park Service and Idaho Department of Parks and Recreation.

images.title: Snake River Overlook in Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument
images.altText: A wooden platform with railing, along with two exhibit signs, overlooks the river and fossil beds.
images.caption: Enjoy scenic vistas and learn about Hagerman's Pliocene past at the Snake River Overlook.

images.title: Oregon Trail Overlook at Hagerman Fossil Beds National Monument
images.altText: An educational exhibit along a trail overlooks panoramic views of the Hagerman Valley.
images.caption: Enjoy scenic vistas and learn about Hagerman's human and paleontological history at the Oregon Trail Overlook.

data.weatherInfo: Hagerman, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year in Hagerman, Idaho. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. Our comfort index, which is based on humidity during the hot months, is a 78 out of 100, where higher is more comfortable. The US average on the comfort index is 44.
data.name: Hagerman Fossil Beds

data.fullName: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail
data.description: At the end of the last Ice Age, 18,000 to 15,000 years ago, an ice dam in northern Idaho created Glacial Lake Missoula stretching 3,000 square miles around Missoula, Montana. The dam burst and released flood waters across Washington, down the Columbia River into Oregon before reaching the Pacific Ocean. The Ice Age Floods forever changed the lives and landscape of the Pacific Northwest.
data.directionsInfo: To Trail Headquarters from Spokane Take I-90 West At Exit 277, merge onto US-2 toward Davenport/Fairchild AFB/Spokane Airport Just past Wilbur, turn right onto WA-21 Stay left onto Highway 174 Turn right onto WA-155 Stay on WA-155 past Grand Coulee Dam and into the town of Coulee Dam Cross the Columbia River and continue on WA-155 Turn right onto Crest Drive and follow up the hill. The HQ Office is located on the left

operatingHours.description: The Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail is a collection of sites operated and owned by a variety of partners. , Hours of operation and season will vary from site to site. Please check each respective site for more details and information.
operatingHours.name: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail

addresses.line2: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

images.caption: Giant springs is a site along the Lewis and Clark National Historic Site located in Great Falls, Montana

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.description: During World War II, over 120,000 people of Japanese ancestry were forcibly removed from their homes and incarcerated without due process of law. Although little remains of the barbed-wire fences and tar-papered barracks, the Minidoka concentration camp once held over 13,000 Japanese Americans in the Idaho desert. Minidoka preserves their legacy and teaches the importance of civil liberties.
data.directionsInfo: Minidoka National Historic Site is located between the towns of Twin Falls and Jerome, Idaho in south central Idaho.

operatingHours.description: The Historic Site is open daily during daylight hours year-round for self-guided tours. Visitor center hours and ranger program offerings vary seasonally. Restrooms are only open during Visitor center operations.
operatingHours.name: Minidoka National Historic Site

images.title: Origami Go Around
images.altText: Origami cranes twirl on carousel
images.caption: Origami cranes twirl on a colorful carousel.

images.title: The Replicated Minidoka Honor Roll
images.altText: The replicated Minidoka Honor Roll is part of the history at Minidoka NHS.
images.caption: The replicated Minidoka Honor Roll is part of the history at Minidoka NHS.

images.title: View Across the Barbed Wire
images.altText: A view from Minidoka through the barbed wire fence.
images.caption: A view from Minidoka through the barbed wire fence.

images.title: Looking at the northside Canal
images.altText: A view of the Northside Canal and reconstructed barbed wire fence.
images.caption: Looking northeast from the entrance area to the Northside Canal and reconstructed barbed wire fence.

images.title: An Original Barrack Returns to the Site
images.altText: An original barrack was retuned to Minidoka and placed on site.
images.caption: An original barrack was retuned to Minidoka and placed on site.

data.weatherInfo: Jerome and Twin Falls, Idaho, gets 10 inches of rain per year. On average, there are 213 sunny days per year here. The July high is around 94 degrees. The January low is 22. High winds are common, and little shade is available at the site.
data.name: Minidoka

data.description: Since time immemorial, the valleys, prairies, mountains, and plateaus of the inland northwest have been home to the nimíipuu (Nez Perce) people. Extremely resilient, they survived the settling of the United States and adapted to a changed world. Nez Perce National Historical Park consists of 38 places important to the history and culture of the nimíipuu. Explore these places. Learn their stories.
data.directionsInfo: Driving south bound on U.S. Highway 95 you will find the Visitor Center 10 miles from Lewiston, ID. Roughly one mile after crossing the Clearwater River you will find the park entrance on your left. When driving north on U.S. Highway 95 the Visitor Center will be 3 miles north of Lapwai, ID. The park entrance will be on your right.

operatingHours.description: Summer visitor center operating hours are 8:30 am - 4:00 pm daily. In the winter, the visitor center is open 5-days a week from Tuesday - Saturday from 8:30 am - 4:00 pm.  Closed Sunday and Monday.  The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's days.
operatingHours.name: Nez Perce National Historical Park, Spalding Visitor Center

images.title: Painted Tipi
images.altText: Colorful painted tipi on green lawn
images.caption: Every morning in the summer Rangers put a tipi on the front lawn of the visitor center. Visitors are always welcome to help.

images.title: Buffalo Eddy
images.altText: Petroglyph carvings on the bank of the Snake River.
images.caption: Buffalo Eddy contains many petroglyphs and is considered a ancient crossing place.

images.title: Take Flight
images.altText: Birds in flight across a grassy field.
images.caption: Birds take flight across a grassy field.

images.title: Buffalo Hide Tipi
images.altText: Elder (Mylie Lawyer) sitting in front of Old Buffalo hide tipi.
images.caption: The only known remaining complete buffalo hide tipi belonging to a Nez Perce.

images.title: Appaloosa Horse Parade
images.altText: Horses and riders dressed in native regalia.
images.caption: This horse parade was held in the Spalding picnic area during the parks 50th anniversary in 2015.

images.title: Weippe Camas
images.altText: Blue Camas flowers in a prairie field.
images.caption: Camas has been a food staple of the Nez Perce for thousands of years.

data.weatherInfo: Elevations in the Park range from 700 feet above sea level to over 8,000, providing a wide range of climatic conditions, that follow the four seasons. Be prepared for very warm weather in the summer months, in particular in the river valleys. The spring and fall are moderate and comfortable. Winter conditions can be severe in the higher elevations, with snow and ice making travel difficult and dangerous. Please visit the National Weather Service for comprehensive weather information.
data.name: Nez Perce

data.description: Imagine yourself an emigrant headed for Oregon: would promises of lush farmlands and a new beginning lure you to leave home and walk for weeks? More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states and serve as reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.
data.directionsInfo: More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states- reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.

operatingHours.description: The Oregon National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Oregon National Historic Trail

images.altText: A wagon swale is cut deep into limestone rock with trees in background.
images.caption: The Guernsey Ruts in Wyoming feature deeply eroded rock from wagon traffic.

images.caption: Devil's Gate was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.title: Alcove Spring Park Wayside

images.caption: Alcove Spring Park is located in Kansas near Blue Rapids and Marysville.

images.title: Split Rock, Wyoming
images.altText: A large yellow flowering desert shrub in front of sagebrush and a large rock buttress.
images.caption: Split Rock was an important emigrant landmark in Wyoming.

images.title: Fort Laramie, Wyoming
images.altText: Two people walk on a green lawn in front of historic fort buildings.
images.caption: Fort Laramie National Historic Site features a replica fort with exhibits, located in eastern Wyoming.

data.description: On March 1, 1872, Yellowstone became the first national park for all to enjoy the unique hydrothermal wonders. Today, millions of people come here each year to camp, hike, and enjoy the majesty of the park.

emailAddresses.description: Contact Yellowstone's park rangers for general park questions, lost and found, or for special use permits.

entranceFees.description: Unlimited entry for one vehicle and all passengers for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase. Vehicles must be private, non-commercial, and with a seating capacity of 15 or less.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Non-commercial group (e.g. church groups, scouts) traveling in a vehicle with a capacity of 16 or more people. Cost is per person. Unlimited entry for one vehicle and all passengers for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Non-commercial Groups

entranceFees.description: Entry for one driver and one passenger for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Entry for one driver and one passenger for seven consecutive days, beginning on the day of purchase.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Snowmobile

entranceFees.description: Entry for visitors on foot, bicycle, ski, etc., when 16 years of age or older.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. The cost is $25 + $20 per person. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: Based upon the total capacity of a vehicle that can carry 7-15 passengers, regardless of the actual number of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Van

entranceFees.description: Based upon the total capacity of a vehicle that can carry 16-25 passengers, regardless of the actual number of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Mini-bus

entranceFees.description: Based upon the total capacity of a vehicle that can carry 26 or more passengers, regardless of the actual number of passengers. A commercial tour is defined as consisting of one or more persons traveling on an itinerary that has been packaged, priced, or sold for leisure or recreational purposes by an organization that realizes financial gain through the provision of the service. Pass is good for seven days as long as it's the same passenger group.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Motor Coach

entrancePasses.description: Provides unlimited entry for one year (valid through the month of purchase) to the pass holder and passengers in the same vehicle, or pass holder and up to three persons where per person fees are charged. Purchase at any entrance station.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Yellowstone National Park covers nearly 3,500 square miles in the northwest corner of Wyoming (3% of the park is in Montana and 1% is in Idaho). Yellowstone has five entrance stations, and several are closed to regular vehicles during winter. It takes many hours to drive between these entrances, so be sure to check the status of roads at the entrance you intend to use while planning your trip and before you arrive.

operatingHours.description:
Yellowstone is open daily, year-round, although activities and services are limited at night and certain times of year. The park has five entrance stations, but not all entrance stations are open year-round. Make sure to carefully read about access at each station at different times of year. And remember, all dates are weather-dependent.

Please note that camping is possible only in designated campgrounds.
operatingHours.name: All Park Hours

operatingHours.description: Adjacent to the town of West Yellowstone, Montana, the West Entrance is usually open (weather-dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow (snowmobiles and snowcoaches) vehicles from December 15 to March 15.
operatingHours.name: West Entrance

operatingHours.description: Near the gateway community of Gardiner, Montana, the North Entrance is the only park entrance open to wheeled vehicles all year. November through April, the North Entrance provides the only access to Cooke City, Montana. US Highway 212 east of Cooke City is closed to wheeled vehicles November through April. The road from Mammoth to Norris opens to wheeled vehicles the third Friday in April through early November, and to tracked-oversnow vehicles, conditions permitting, from December 15 to early March.
operatingHours.name: North Entrance

operatingHours.description: Depending on the weather and conditions, this entrance usually opens to wheeled vehicles the first Friday in May and to tracked-oversnow vehicles December 22 through March 15.
operatingHours.name: East Entrance

operatingHours.description: Open (weather-dependent) to wheeled vehicles from the second Friday in May through early November and to tracked-oversnow vehicles from December 15 to March 15. Limited services are available near the South Entrance.
operatingHours.name: South Entrance

operatingHours.description: Near the gateway communities of Silver Gate and Cooke City, Montana, this entrance is open year around for wheeled vehicle access to Cooke City through Gardiner, Montana. US Highway 212 east of Cooke City is closed to wheeled vehicles November through April. Opening dates for roads east of Cooke City vary from year to year, depending on the weather. The Beartooth Highway is open from late May/early June (weather dependent) to mid October.
operatingHours.name: Northeast Entrance

images.title: Grand Prismatic Spring
images.altText: Brilliant blues and greens of a hot spring ringed by oranges, yellows, reds, and browns.
images.caption: The bright colors found in Grand Prismatic Spring come from thermophiles—microorganisms that thrive in hot temperatures

images.title: Aurum Geyser
images.altText: A crowd of people standing along a wooden boardwalk watches a geyser erupt.
images.caption: Aurum Geyser erupting

images.title: Black Pool
images.altText: A visitor stands on a boardwalk near a hot spring and a lake.
images.caption: Black Pool at the West Thumb Geyser Basin

images.title: Beehive Geyser
images.altText: People on a wooden boardwalk watch a geyser erupt.
images.caption: Visitors to the Upper Geyser Basin watch Beehive Geyser erupt.

images.title: Wolf howling
images.altText: A wolf howls while standing on a snowy field.
images.caption: Alpha male of the Canyon wolf pack

images.title: Fishing Bridge Trailside Museum
images.altText: Visitors walk into a rustic, log and stone building.
images.caption: The stone-and-log architecture of Fishing Bridge Trailside Museum became a prototype for park buildings all around the country

images.title: Great Fountain Geyser
images.altText: A geyser erupting in the middle of a large pool.
images.caption: Great Fountain Geyser erupts against a blue summer sky

images.title: Old Faithful Geyser in winter
images.altText: A crowd in front of an erupting geyser during a snowy winter day.
images.caption: Winter is a magical time to watch Old Faithful Geyser erupt

images.title: Palette Spring
images.altText: Visitors walk in front of a brightly colored, terraced landscape.
images.caption: The vibrant colors of Palette Springs are formed by thermophiles—heat-loving organisms

images.title: Bighorn sheep
images.altText: Two bighorn sheep laying on the ground.
images.caption: Two bighorn rams rest and chew their cud

images.title: Lower Falls from Artist Point
images.altText: A river plunges into a steep, barren canyon.
images.caption: Lower Falls from Artist Point

images.title: Bison herd in a thermal area
images.altText: A herd of bison grazing through a barren and steaming thermal area.
images.caption: Bison near Mud Volcano

images.title: Grizzly bear
images.altText: A grizzly bear standing on a fallen tree.
images.caption: Grizzly bear in the woods

images.title: Yellowstone River
images.altText: A greenish river meanders through a hilly river valley.
images.caption: The Yellowstone River near Tower Fall

data.weatherInfo: Yellowstone's weather can vary quite a bit, even in a single day. In the summer, daytime highs can exceed 70°F (21°C), only to drop 20 or more degrees when a thunderstorm rolls through. It can snow during any month of the year, and winter lows frequently drop below 0°F (-18°C), especially at night. Bring a range of clothing options, including a warm jacket and rain gear, even in the summer.
data.name: Yellowstone
